One major life thesis I have developed (living in the US but this can obviously apply elsewhere) is that I come from a society that hates culture. What a weird thing to say, and how much stranger that it is clearly true. Our national disposition is one that is downright loathsome of all the humanities, going so far as to pit the social against the science (as if that makes any sense at all).


Further, we rig the game, and measure the winner in a way that leaves things like art, music, and even theater with a score of 0. "It's not useful" is the sentiment. Music theory doesn't build bridges, sculptures don't make electricity, and an actor's performance only ships goods across a continent if they are very deep in method acting a truck driver.

Find any post on social media about college grads not making enough money, and I guarantee you, there will be someone in the comments disparaging worthless "art degrees" or "gender studies" or whatever, implying, or sometimes just outright saying, that people who pursue certain fields deserve to be part of the demeaned working poor.

This series opened my eyes to just how much contempt we have for theater and how we are blatantly denying one of the most human endeavors of all time. My background here was absolutely pathetic. Usually with Crash Course series, I have something of a functioning framework to hang the new knowledge on, helping it make sense and making it easier to retain. In this series, it was basically all brand new from start to finish. I knew I was going to have to immediately rewatch the series less than half-way in.

Thanks Mike, for once again bringing a YouTube series that's eye opening, thought provoking, and intellectually nourishing. Your impact on my life continues to be endlessly positive and helpful, and there is no way I would be the person I am today without the work you have done.
Thank you so much for this series! I passed my Theatre Praxis exam with a lot of help from this Crash Course :)

Some of these revolutions of Oklahoma were already being done in Opera. Most composers would always have a libretto first and then set the music to the words, Wagner wrote his own so it's possible he wrote the music first I'm not sure. Also the plots were not always fantastical, verismo operas like La Boheme featured multifaceted characters in real situations with no Aria or duet not moving the plot forward. The musical owes so much to Opera and it is worth more than a brief mention. I hope you all are doing a history of music and It'll cover the art form because if not the exclusion of Opera in this series is a major mistake.

"First Guys and Dolls, and then Artaud" truer words have never been said. I've loved this series- it's been wonderful and informative and really fun. And thank you for including an episode on Artaud, not enough people embrace ritualistic madness any more!  Thank you so much :)

I saw the Toronto revival of Showboat when I was in high school in roughly  1994.  yeah yeah... I'm old now.   lol.  When we place the racial politics in the time it was set I don't see why a revival couldn't happen today.  Yes, the racist overtones are jarring but they are a product of the time the play was set and frankly part of the story the play told.   When treated as a quasi historical play it has great story to tell.

Thanks for a great series! You left out the Yiddish theater in New York  which is basically what created the Broadway show. The musical Oklahoma was popular because free tickets were given to any serviceman or woman who appeared at the box office in uniform. Some of them on leave would see the show many times.
